DOCNAME: CASE OF DE CUBBER v. BELGIUM
TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant is a NORP citizen born in DATE . He lives in GPE and is a sales manager .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , he was arrested by the police at his home and taken to NORP where he was questioned in connection with a car theft .

Warrants of arrest for forgery and uttering forged documents were issued against the applicant on DATE , on DATE and on DATE . The first warrant - notice no . CARDINAL.CARDINAL/CARDINAL - was issued by Mr. PERSON , an investigating judge at the NORP criminal court ( tribunal correctionnel ) , and the second and third - notices nos . ORG and CARDINAL - by Mr. PERSON , the other investigating judge at the same court .

CARDINAL . ORG Prior to that , in the capacity of judge ( juge assesseur ) of the same court sitting either on appeal ( judgment of CARDINAL DATE ) or at first instance ( judgments of DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE ) , Mr. PERSON had already dealt with criminal proceedings brought against Mr. PERSON in connection with a number of offences ; those proceedings had led variously to an unconditional or conditional discharge ( relaxe ) ( DATE and DATE , respectively ) or to conviction .

More recently , Mr. PERSON had had to examine , in his capacity of investigating judge , a criminal complaint filed by Mr. PERSON ( DATE ) and , in his capacity of judge dealing with the attachment of property ( juge des saisies ) , certain civil cases concerning him ( DATE ) . In regard to each of these cases , the applicant had applied to ORG to have the case removed , on the ground of bias ( suspicion légitime ; Article CARDINAL of the Judicial Code ) , from Mr. PERSON or from the NORP court as a whole ; each of these requests had been held inadmissible or unfounded .

CARDINAL . ORG At the outset Mr. PERSON dealt with cases nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL but he was on several occasions prevented by illness from attending his chambers . He was replaced , initially on an occasional and temporary basis and , as from DATE , on a permanent basis , by Mr. PERSON , who retained responsibility for case no . CARDINAL.CARDINAL/CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . ORG In case no . CARDINAL , a single - judge chamber of the NORP court ( Mr. PERSON ) sentenced Mr. PERSON on DATE to DATE imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL BF . He did not appeal against this decision .

CARDINAL . ORG After preliminary investigations lasting DATE , a chamber of the court ( the chambre du conseil ) ordered the joinder of cases nos . CARDINAL.CARDINAL/CARDINAL and ORG and on CARDINAL DATE committed Mr. PERSON for trial . These cases related to CARDINAL alleged offences committed by CARDINAL accused , headed by the applicant ; there were CARDINAL persons intervening to claim damages ( parties civiles ) .

For the purpose of the trial , the court , which over DATE had CARDINAL or CARDINAL titular judges , sat as a chamber composed of a president and CARDINAL judges , including Mr. PERSON . Mr. PERSON stated that he protested orally against the latter ’s presence , but he did not have recourse to any of the legal remedies open to him for this purpose , such as a formal challenge ( procédure de récusation ; LAW ) .

After a hearing which lasted DATE on CARDINAL and DATE , the court gave judgment on DATE . Mr. PERSON was acquitted on CARDINAL counts and convicted on the remainder , note being taken of the fact that he was a recidivist . He was accordingly sentenced , in respect of CARDINAL matter , to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL BF and , in respect of another , to DATE imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL BF ; his immediate arrest was ordered .

CARDINAL . ORG Both the applicant and the public prosecutor ’s department appealed . On DATE , ORG reduced the first sentence to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment and a fine of CARDINAL BF and upheld the second . In addition , it unanimously imposed a third sentence , namely DATE imprisonment and a fiscal fine ( amende fiscale ) , for offences which the NORP court had - wrongly , in ORG view - treated as being linked with others by reason of a single criminal intent .

CARDINAL . ORG Mr. PERSON appealed to ORG , raising some CARDINAL different points of law . CARDINAL of his grounds , based on LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the LAW , was that Mr. PERSON had been both judge and party in the case since after conducting the preliminary investigation he had acted as CARDINAL of the trial judges .

ORG gave judgment on DATE ( Pasicrisie DATE , I , pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . It held that this combination of functions violated neither LAW nor any other legal provision - such as LAW para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the Convention - nor the rights of the defence . On the other hand , ORG upheld a plea concerning the confiscation of certain items of evidence and , to this extent , referred the case back to ORG ; the latter court has in the meantime ( on DATE ) directed that the items in question be returned . ORG also quashed , of its own motion and without referring the case back , the decision under appeal in so far as the appellant had been sentenced to a fiscal fine . The remainder of the appeal was dismissed .

CARDINAL . ORG Investigating judges , who are appointed by the Crown " from among the judges of the court of first instance " ( LAW ) , conduct the preparatory judicial investigation ( Articles CARDINAL et seq . of LAW ) . The object of this procedure is to assemble the evidence and to establish any proof against the accused as well as any circumstances that may tell in his favour , so as to provide the chambre du conseil or the chambre des mises en accusation , as the case may be , with the material which it needs to decide whether the accused should be committed for trial . The procedure is secret ; it is not conducted in the presence of both parties ( non contradictoire ) nor is there any legal representation .

The investigating judge also has the status of officer of the criminal investigation police ( police judiciaire ) . In this capacity , he is empowered to inquire into serious and lesser offences ( crimes et délits ) , to assemble evidence and to receive complaints from any person claiming to have been prejudiced by such offences ( Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL in fine and CARDINAL of LAW ) . When so acting , he is placed under the " supervision of the procureur général ( ORG prosecutor ) " ( LAW CARDINAL of the Judicial Code ) , although this does not include a power to give directions . " In all cases where the suspected offender is deemed to have been caught in the act " , the investigating judge may take " directly " and in person " any action which the procureur du Roi ( public prosecutor ) is empowered to take " ( Article CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Save in the latter category of case , the investigating judge can take action only after the matter has been referred to him either by means of a formal request from the procureur du Roi for the opening of an inquiry ( Articles DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure ) or by means of a criminal complaint coupled with a claim for damages ( constitution de partie civile ; Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

If a court includes several investigating judges , it is for the presiding judge to allocate cases amongst them . In principle , cases are assigned to them in turn , from DATE ; however , this is not an inflexible rule and the presiding judge may depart therefrom , for example if the matter is urgent or if a new case has some connection with one that has already been allocated .

CARDINAL . ORG In order to facilitate the ascertainment of the truth , the investigating judge is invested with wide powers ; according to the case - law of ORG , he may " take any steps which are not forbidden by law or incompatible with the standing of his office " ( judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Pasicrisie DATE , I , p. CARDINAL ) . He can , inter alia , summon the accused to appear or issue a warrant for his detention , production before a court or arrest ( Articles CARDINAL et seq . of LAW ) ; question the accused , hear witnesses ( Articles DATE and CARDINAL of the same Code ) , confront witnesses with each other ( Article CARDINAL of the Judicial Code ) , visit the scene of the crime ( Article CARDINAL of LAW ) , visit and search LOC ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the same Code ) , take possession of evidence ( LAW ) , and so on . The investigating judge has to report to the chambre du conseil on the cases with which he is dealing ( LAW ) ; he takes , by means of an order , decisions on the expediency of measures requested by the public prosecutor ’s department , such orders being subject to an appeal to the chambre des mises en accusation of ORG .
CARDINAL . When the investigation is completed , the investigating judge transmits the case - file to the procureur du Roi , who will return it to him with his submissions ( LAW , first paragraph ) .

It is then for the chambre du conseil , which is composed of a single judge belonging to the court of first instance ( Acts of DATE , CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE ) , to decide - unless it considers it should order further inquiries - whether to discharge the accused ( non - lieu ; LAW ) , to commit him for trial before a district court ( tribunal de police ; Article CARDINAL ) or a criminal court ( tribunal correctionnel ; Article CARDINAL ) or to send the papers to the procureur général attached to ORG ( Article CARDINAL ) , depending upon the circumstances .

Unlike his NORP counterpart , the NORP investigating judge is thus never empowered to refer a case to the trial court himself . Before taking its decision , the chambre du conseil - which sits in camera - will hear the investigating judge ’s report . This report will take the form of an oral account of the state of the investigations ; the investigating judge will express no opinion therein as to the accused ’s guilt , it being for the public prosecutor ’s department to deliver concluding submissions calling for CARDINAL decision or another .

CARDINAL . ORG Article CARDINAL of the DATE LAW prohibits " the concurrent exercise of different judicial functions ... except where otherwise provided by law " ; it lays down that " any decision given by a judge who has previously dealt with the case in the exercise of some other judicial function " shall be null and void .

This rule applies to investigating judges , amongst others . Article CARDINAL specifies that " proceedings before an assize court shall be null and void if the presiding judge or another judge sitting is a judicial officer who has acted in the case as investigating judge ... " .

Neither can an investigating judge sit as an appeal - court judge , for otherwise he would have " to review on appeal , and thus as last - instance trial judge , the legality of investigation measures ... which [ he ] had taken or ordered at first instance " ( Court of Cassation , DATE , Pasicrisie DATE , I , p. CARDINAL , and Revue de droit pénal et de criminologie , DATE , pp . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On the other hand , under the third paragraph of LAW , as amended by LAW of DATE , " investigating judges may continue to sit , in accordance with their seniority , to try cases brought before a court of first instance " . According to the drafting history and decided case - law on this provision , it is immaterial that the cases are ones previously investigated by the judges in question : they would in that event be exercising , not " some other judicial function " within the meaning of Article CARDINAL , but rather the same function of judge on the court of first instance ; it would be only their assignment that had changed ( Parliamentary Documents , ORG , no . CARDINAL of DATE ; ORG , DATE , Pasicrisie DATE , I , p. CARDINAL - CARDINAL ; ORG judgment of DATE in the present case , see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

In the case of PERSON , ORG confirmed this line of authority in its judgment of DATE , which followed the submissions presented by the public prosecutor ’s department . After dismissing various arguments grounded on general principles of law , ORG rejected the argument put forward by the appellant on the basis of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) of the Convention :

" However , as regards the application of LAW para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) ... , when a case requires a determination of civil rights and obligations or of a criminal charge , the authority hearing the case at first instance and the procedure followed by that authority do not necessarily have to satisfy the conditions laid down by the above - mentioned provision , provided that the party concerned or the accused is able to lodge an appeal against the decision affecting him taken by that authority with a court which does offer all the guarantees stipulated by LAW CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) and has competence to review all questions of fact and of law . In the present case , the appellant does not maintain that the court of appeal which convicted him did not offer those guarantees ...
In any event , the principles and the rule relied on in the ground of appeal do not have the scope therein suggested ;

From the sole fact that a trial judge inquired into the case as an investigating judge it can not be inferred that the accused ’s right to an impartial court has been violated . It can not legitimately be feared that the said judge does not offer the guarantees of impartiality to which every accused is entitled .

The investigating judge is not a party adverse to the accused , but a judge of the court of first instance with the responsibility of assembling in an impartial manner evidence in favour of as well as against the accused .
